moves.1. e4: This was  a complicated game played well by my opponent. I will work on this over the next few days. Feel free to comment.
moves.1... c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6: A Sicilian Dragon. I play this as black occasionaly and understand some of the ideas, but it is complicated.
moves.6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 O-O 8. Qd2 Nc6 9. O-O-O: All standard theory as far as I recall, with maybe some transpositions.
moves.12. h4: Going for an attack. Alternatives are 12. Bh6 or 12. Kb1
moves.12... Nxb3+: Normal here is 12... Nc4  13. Bxc4 Rxc4 , forcing an exchange and bringing the rook to c4
moves.13. Nxb3: Preferable to any pawn recaptures, which may weaken the queenside
moves.13... h5: Seems sensible but ultimately may be weakening the kingside
moves.14. Bg5: Trying for a tactic based on the idea of e5, de, bxf6 and taking twice on d7
moves.15. Kb1 Rc4: Now the above  tactic is on again, with the back rank weakened.
moves.16. e5 Ne8 17. exd6: Not the only option. White could have continued with 17. Nd5 Bxd5 18. Qxd5
moves.18. Bh6: Going for an exchange of the powerful dragon bishop
moves.18... Bh8: Interesting, sometimes it is worth sacrificing the exchange to keep the bishop
moves.19. Bxf8 Qxf8 20. g4 hxg4 21. h5: Sacrificing material for a direct attack on the king
moves.21... Qg7 22. hxg6 Qxg6 23. fxg4 Rxg4: A difficult position to assess and play, with black having the 2 bishops both baring down on the white queenside. I am trying to create threats of my own and watch out for mate
moves.24. Nc5: The knight was not doing much on b3 so I tried to activate it
moves.24... Bf5: Maybe Bg7 here, with 24...Bg7 25. Nxe6 Qxe6
moves.25... Qg7: Threatening mate on b2, but white has a check and a tricky combination first
moves.26. Nxe7+ Kf8 27. Rxh8+ Qxh8 28. Qxd6: winning a piece by giving the exchange back
moves.28... Bxc2+: I eventually figured out that taking back on c2 would allow annoying checks from the queen and rook, so I decided to delay the capture, black is forced to get her king and queen out of the way
moves.29. Kc1 Kg7 30. Kxc2 Qh7+ 31. Kb3: I was bit surprised black resigned with the queens still on the board, but white is well ahead in material. Still, plenty of room for mistakes by both sides.

opening: Sicilian (B76), dragon, Yugoslav attack, Rauser variation
